Author: wolfgang#3508
Content: little confused about how it all works. Isn't SEC based in the US?  So if someone launches something that could according to them be considered a secuirty in some place like South East Asia.  Do they have a right to shut them down>

Author: meatspoon#7860
Content: @wolfgang  I am envious.  I was late to the party.  I started dollar cost averaging into BCO about halfway thru this year.  Very excited for what the future holds for BCO.  Passive income coins tickle me in all the right places.

Author: meatspoon#7860
Content: Good question, I am not sure.  I would imagine there are lots of ways that the SEC can apply pressure outside of the US borders (in addition to it being very FUD'y if the SEC singles a project out).  The SEC could probably lean on whatever government to try and get them to do their bidding.  So CB's solution I think has a good shot.  The devs are anonymous and they are trying to make it so they can completely step away from the project and just let the gateways handle things.  So in theory, a gateway could get shut down if it were in a jurisdiction controlled or influenced by the SEC... but that would be just one coin on an exchange and someone on the other side of the world could reopen that same coin/gateway.

Content: or I suppose the SEC could go after Bitshares, but that network might be too robust at this point to bring it to heel.  The future is going to be very interesting to watch

Author: snowdamn#2414
Content:
all loopholes end as soon as there is need to convert back to fiat
they can simply say you can't present exchanges from DEX as source  (if not that they are outright illegal)

Author: meatspoon#7860
Content: I think I understand your first statement, and I agree for the time being.

Author: meatspoon#7860
Content: in your second, are you saying that the IRS or SEC would say that someone filing taxes can't submit trades made on a DEX or that they could just make DEX's illegal?

Author: snowdamn#2414
Content:
yes, i'm saying that they can simply do the former
if they don't make it outright illegal

Author: meatspoon#7860
Content: Well, i am no lawyer (nor am I a rocket surgeon), but I don't think it would be in the IRS's best interest to tell people they werent allowed to voluntarily declare income.  As for making something illegal, I think Congress has to do that.  The SEC can apply pressure and make claims that organizations are not in compliance, but I don't think the SEC typically goes after individuals that arent whales

Author: meatspoon#7860
Content: so if a DEX has millions of users, the SEC is going to go after the DEX, not the users, right?

Author: snowdamn#2414
Content: yes, SEC doesn't make the laws and its jurisdiction is to go after owners, operators, beneficiaries, etc.

Author: snowdamn#2414
Content: on the corporation level

Author: meatspoon#7860
Content: fair enough, just as a police officer's job is to go after, say, drug dealers... but they don't typically mess with an individual who has a dime bag in his pocket

Author: meatspoon#7860
Content: so in the example that wolfgang and i were making, that of CryptoBridge, its hard to guess how the SEC might try to apply pressure.

Author: snowdamn#2414
Content:
i was talking from a user perspective
sorry if i changed subject

Author: meatspoon#7860
Content: no, thats ok.  Obviously, as a user, i am very interested in that perspective too

Author: meatspoon#7860
Content: for me, i will be reporting my BCO staking payouts with my taxes.  I am curious to see how my accountant handles it.  She is gonna hate me.

Author: meatspoon#7860
Content: right now i think the IRS is playing catch-up.  I think the people who declare their crypto income aren't gonna get messed with much and I doubt the IRS will be taking note of different exchanges (yet).  My hope is that CryptoBridge (and other DEX's) get off the ground and become essentially unstoppable before the alphabet soup agencies even take note of their existence
